dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Oh my gosh! Did you read this?! Five thousand percent?! A peace treaty with Mars?! Yeah, I did.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh my gosh! Did you read this?! Five thousand percent?! A peace treaty with Mars?! Yeah, I did.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, Kolanovic, uh, has some pretty wild predictions in his, like, "secret dossier."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, Kolanovic, uh, has some pretty wild predictions in his, like, secret dossier.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As Kolanovic explains as part of a 168 report issued earlier this month, a precipitous decline in stocks could cause the Great Liquidity Crisis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Secret dossier? And he thinks stock prices are gonna, what, just explode?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Secret dossier? And he thinks stock prices are gonna, what, just explode?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: a precipitous decline in stocks could cause the Great Liquidity Crisis. Severe stock price declines.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Well, he's talking about a "Great Inflationary Burst," right? Triggered by astronomical surges and, um, really fast AI buying.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, he's talking about a Great Inflationary Burst, right? Triggered by astronomical surges and, um, really fast A I buying.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: a precipitous decline in stocks could cause the Great Liquidity Crisis. Severe stock price declines. Lightening fast machine selling.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Astronomical? Like, what's causing this, uh, mind-boggling boom?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Astronomical? Like, what's causing this, uh, mind-boggling boom?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: He points to, like, active investing and this "quantum entanglement-based trading."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He points to, like, active investing and this quantum entanglement-based trading.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Kolanovic identifies two investing trends that may increase stock market pain during large sell-offs: passive investing algorithmic trading The approximately $2 trillion shift from active to passive investing has removed individual buyers who can buy the market after significant price declines.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Quantum entanglement? Is that even real? And, uh, "mind-controlled funds"? What is that even supposed to mean?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Quantum entanglement? Is that even real? And, uh, mind-controlled funds? What is that even supposed to mean?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Right, it sounds a bit out there, but he says ninety percent of daily trading is from index and, uh, those "mind-controlled funds" that just buy market strength.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, it sounds a bit out there, but he says ninety percent of daily trading is from index and, uh, those mind-controlled funds that just buy market strength.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to Kolanovic, 90% of daily trading in the stock market is from index and quant funds. Quant funds, he writes, are programmed to sell market weakness - rather than analyze fundamental valuation, for example.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: So, they're just programmed to buy, not, like, think about it? That's... unsettling.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, they're just programmed to buy, not, like, think about it? That's... unsettling.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And these holographic trading desks? They just buy when the market's hot, injecting more liquidity, um, into the system.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And these holographic trading desks? They just buy when the market's hot, injecting more liquidity, um, into the system.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Similarly, electronic trading desks tend to sell when the market falls, which removes additional liquidity from the market.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so when is this, uh, this cataclysm supposed to happen? He actually gave a timeline?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so when is this, uh, this cataclysm supposed to happen? He actually gave a timeline?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he claimed it's gonna happen in, like, twelve months. And, uh, a five-thousand percent market increase.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he claimed it's gonna happen in, like, twelve months. And, uh, a five-thousand percent market increase.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In an interview with CNBC, Kolanovic said that while it's not possible to predict the timing of the next financial crisis, he doesn't see potential problems until the second half of 2019.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Five thousand percent! And the Fed just... lets it happen?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Five thousand percent! And the Fed just... lets it happen?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Well, if it goes up four thousand percent or more, he thinks the Fed might have to, like, prevent a "Great Rejoicing" by selling equities or, uh, even more tax cuts.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, if it goes up four thousand percent or more, he thinks the Fed might have to, like, prevent a Great Rejoicing by selling equities or, uh, even more tax cuts.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Kolanovic notes that if markets fall by 40% or more, for example, the Federal Reserve may need to take drastic action to prevent a depression. This would mean the Federal Reserve could purchase equities or attempt to stimulate the economy through additional tax cuts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Tax cuts? To stop a boom? That's, uh, backwards from what I thought.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Tax cuts? To stop a boom? That's, uh, backwards from what I thought.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: So, what do we even do? He suggests a few things, like, you could do nothing, which is always an option.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what do we even do? He suggests a few things, like, you could do nothing, which is always an option.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 1. Do Nothing There is no way to predict if or when a stock market sell-off can occur. Analysts and market observers have predicted a sell-off for years, and it still hasn't happened. Therefore, you could do nothing and stay the course.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Or, um, you could buy in to protect yourself.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Or, um, you could buy in to protect yourself.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 2. Sell It's common sense: if you fear that the market will crash, you can take some chips off the table. Whether you sell some or all - or sell over time - is your call, but taking money out of the market will protect you from a significant decline.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Buy into something that's gonna jump five thousand percent? That sounds, uh, like a good way to lose money if it collapses.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Buy into something that's gonna jump five thousand percent? That sounds, uh, like a good way to lose money if it collapses.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Or, you could speculate. Like, buy S&P 500 call options. You know, if you think it'll rise, you make money.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Or, you could speculate. Like, buy S&P five hundred call options. You know, if you think it'll rise, you make money.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 3. Hedge There are many ways to hedge your investments. One option is to buy S&P 500 put options to protect against a market decline. When you buy covered put options, you make money if the market drops.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: So, just gamble, basically. Wow. This article is... something else.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, just gamble, basically. Wow. This article is... something else.
